name: Jökulsá á Fjöllum Bridge
description:
The Jökulsá á Fjöllum Bridge is an impressive steel arch bridge carrying Route 1 (Ring Road) across Iceland's second-longest river, Jökulsá á Fjöllum, in the remote northeastern highlands. Completed in 2009, this modern bridge replaced an older structure and represents a significant achievement in Icelandic civil engineering. The bridge spans 278 meters with its distinctive red-painted arch rising 45 meters above the turbulent glacial river below. The Jökulsá á Fjöllum originates from Vatnajökull glacier and carries enormous volumes of glacial meltwater, making bridging it a substantial engineering challenge requiring foundations capable of withstanding powerful currents and potential glacial floods.

The bridge location offers spectacular views up and down the river canyon, with the braided glacial river visible both upstream and downstream. The surrounding landscape showcases the dramatic highlands terrain with volcanic formations and sparse vegetation. The bridge is positioned between two of Iceland's most impressive waterfalls: Dettifoss (Europe's most powerful waterfall) lies approximately 25 kilometers upstream, while Selfoss waterfall is visible in the distance. The bridge has become a landmark on the northeast section of the Ring Road, marking the transition from coastal areas into the more remote northeastern regions. Its distinctive red color makes it highly photogenic against the grey volcanic landscape.

The bridge is located on Route 1 in the Jökulsárgljúfur area, approximately 35 kilometers south of Ásbyrgi canyon. Small parking areas on both sides of the bridge allow visitors to stop safely and photograph the structure. The bridge is accessible year-round, though winter driving conditions in this area can be challenging. Many travelers stop here briefly while journeying between Akureyri and Egilsstaðir or when visiting nearby Dettifoss and Ásbyrgi. The bridge represents crucial infrastructure connecting eastern and northern Iceland, as alternative routes would require lengthy detours.
